poem:
**Freedom Browses Shelves**

In a corner of the world,  
small bookshops whisper tales,  
bound by oceans and quiet sails.  
Words once silent,  
now flutter like birds,  
carrying echoes of flames past,  
sheltered beneath foreign roofs.  
A sense of freedom nestles  
between the spines,  
where the world unfolds  
page by page.  
Exploration, a new beginning.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘A sense of freedom’: China’s small bookshops relocate across the world On 24 November, exactly two years after a fire in an apartment building in Xinjiang killed 10 people and sparked a wave of historic protests across China, two dozen people gathered in a small bookshop in the Netherlands to reflect on the event. “When anger becomes infectious, / when words are seen to be dangerous, / leave me blank, please!” Hongwei Bao, an associate". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
